titleStmt.title: Letter from Henrietta G. Andrews. July 10, 1929.
titleStmt.author: Henrietta G. Andrews

publicationStmt.p: This document forms part of the project "Editing the Earth M.M. White Collection" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

msContents.summary: Author writes to members of the Florida State Federation of Colored Women's Clubs as the newly elected president of the organization.

objectDesc.p: A single page typed letter with the Florida State Federation of Colored Women's Clubs header.

editorialDecl.p: This file was transcribed and encoded according to the editorial criteria of the project "Editing the Eartha M.M. White Collection." Using the various options encoded within <choice> elements, this file enables the viewing of a diplomatic transcription and a regularized reading text.

div.opener:
Jacksonville, Florida,
July 10, 1929
To the Club Women of Florida,
Greetings:
div.p:
The Twenty-Second Annual Session of the State Federation of Colored Women's Clubs has
just closed a most harmonious and successful meeting in West Palm Beach.

I want to thank you for your unanimous vote for me as your president. I appreciate the
honor that has been conferred upon me and the trust that you have placed in me as your presi
dent. I shall endeavor with the assistance of Him who knoweth no failure and with the co
operation of every woman to push out program to a successful completion. How well I do
this depends on the support I recieve from you.

Realizing the splendid record of achievements of the women, who have preceeded me in
this distinguished office and knowing the part that Negro women are to play the the civic af
fairs of this state and knowing that the world today listens only to organized groups;, the State
Federation knows what organized womanhood must do for Florida and therefore must speak
in tones that will break down the doors of prejudice that is daily practiced against us.

Our organization must be strengthened at every weak point and our women must cooper
ate. In our state meeting we adopted a scholarship fund for some worthy student, who has
finished high school, which is truly a great step forward for our women. I therefore, set aside
the second Sunday in March 1930 as an educational day for the Club Women in Florida.

All adult and junior clubs in each city will get-to-getherget together, arrange a program, select your
church or auditorium in which to hold your meeting. Talk about it in your clubs, in the
churches, through the press, on the streets, in the schools and everywhere. Have a great
rally.

Send all money to the secretary, Dr. E. C. Hampton, 803 South Magnolia Street, Ocala,
made payable to the State Federation of Colored Womens Clubs, and she will send it to the tre
asurer, who will mail you a receipt for same. Please send a copy, of all letters in which money
is sent, to me.

All Clubsclubs that have donated this year are asked to donate something toward the debt of
the two women, who took care of the children, who were in the Home for Delinquent girls at
Ocala. Those who have not paid their state and national dues are asked to please pay them and
pay something on the debt, we owe these two women. This is an old debt of long standing
ladies but it is ours. Will you please help us pay these women? Will you please respond
as quickly as possible? We owe $49.00 to one $26.00 to the other and we have no money at
all. Mrs. Jackson, the lady, who worked so long is seriously ill and needs her money badly.
She is unable to walk.

Our slogan is one hundred new Clubsclubs and five hundred new members. Depending on each
and every one of you and pledging my every effort to the upbuilding of our very worthy organi
zation, I am,

closer.signed:
Henrietta G. Andrews,
President.
State Federation of Colored Women's Clubs.
